author: trent_vanepps
content:
what is this error on the site? i feel like this isn't something that should be presented to users as there is nothing actionable. during the "waiting for sequencer step

> Your call to the sequencer came too early. Remember that there is a specific time interval between calls

futher - during this step the `view contributions` button is presented, but would take participants out of the contribution flow when they click on it

author: trent_vanepps
content: <@992497067878518875> <@405860945018093609> should we get ceremony.ethereum.eth now that we've got the IPFS working?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nicoserranop> > <nicoserranop>  1. You are right, the call to the sequencer is done automatically. When/how you got this error? I will try to replicate it

2. The view contributions button is not done yet. I am finishing up the modals to show the details today. The view contributions button takes you out of the flow but it should only appear on the home page and on the completed contribution page (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <Trent> what is this error on the site? i feel like this isn't something that should be presented to users as there is nothing actionable. during the "waiting for sequencer step

> Your call to the sequencer came too early. Remember that there is a specific time interval between calls

futher - during this step the `view contributions` button is presented, but would take participants out of the contribution flow when they click on it)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<trent_vanepps> > <trent_vanepps>  1. the error appears when just going through regularly, i didn't do anything special
2. ok, great! didn't realize that part was still being modified (re @nicoserranop: 1. You are right, the call to the sequencer is done automatically. When/how you got this error? I will try to replicate it

2. The view contributions button is not done yet. I am finishing up the modals to show the details today. The view contributions button takes you out of the flow but it should only appear on the home page and on the completed contribution page)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nicoserranop> > <nicoserranop>  @glamperd suggested to have the IPFS frontend in a "public" known infrastructure (Pinata) instead of  in our domain because any private config or server in the loop could be seen as an opportunity to distort the content.

The IPFS hash would allow any user to pin the content and use the frontend without any custom configuration. The HTTP headers issue was completely removed (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <Trent> <@992497067878518875> @glamperd should we get ceremony.ethereum.eth now that we've got the IPFS working?)

content:

2. ok, great! didn't realize that part was still being modified)
